Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Expectation2: Assist patients with daily living activities such as bathing, dressing, and eating
Situation2: A patient is recovering from a recent surgery and requires more careful assistance to move and get dressed.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was about to help Mr. Lee, who was still groggy from his surgery, sit up and get dressed. I glanced at the screen and saw a message from my friend, Sarah. Her words stung: “I can’t believe you’d say that. I thought you understood me.” My heart dropped. She’d misread my earlier text, and I knew if I didn’t call her right away, the misunderstanding would only grow. But Mr. Lee was waiting, his face anxious, his movements slow and unsteady. He needed my full attention to make sure he didn’t fall or hurt himself. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing on me—Sarah expecting me to be the friend who always listens and explains, Mr. Lee relying on me to be the steady, caring nursing assistant. My mind raced, torn between the urge to fix things with Sarah and the responsibility to keep my patient safe. I stood there, phone in hand, heart pounding, caught between two people who needed me in completely different ways.
